{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2009 |Team=Stanford Cardinal |Image=Stanford plain block "S" logo.svg |ImageSize=100 px |Conference=Pacific-10 Conference |Division= |ShortConference=Pac-10 |Record=8â5 |ConfRecord=6â3 |CoachRank= |BCSRank= |APRank= |HeadCoach=[[Jim Harbaugh]] |OffCoach= [[David Shaw (American football)|David Shaw]] |DefCoach= Andy Buh
[[Ron Lynn]] |OScheme= |DScheme= [[4â3 defense|4-3]] |StadiumArena=[[Stanford Stadium]] |Champion= |BowlTourney=[[2009 Sun Bowl|Sun Bowl]] vs. [[2009 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]] |BowlTourneyResult=L 27â31 |uniform=File:Pac-10-Uniform-SU-2008-2009.png }} {{2009 Pacific-10 football standings}} The 2009 '''[[Stanford Cardinal football]]''' team represented [[Stanford University]] during the [[2009 NCAA Division I FBS football season]]. The Cardinal was [[head coach|coached]] by third-year coach [[Jim Harbaugh]] and played their home games at [[Stanford Stadium]] in [[Stanford, California]]. ==Recruiting== Stanford's 2009 recruiting class was ranked 15th in the nation by [[Scout.com]]{{cite web|url=http://recruiting.scout.com/a.z?s=73&p=9&c=14&yr=2009|title=Scout.com Team Recruiting Rankings|publisher=[[Scout.com]]|accessdate=2009-09-29}} and 20th by [[Rivals.com]],{{cite web|url=http://rivals100.rivals.com/TeamRank.asp?postype=0&sort=0&year=2009|title=2009 Team Ranking|publisher=[[Rivals.com]]|accessdate=2009-09-29}} and included these top-rated recruits:{{cite web|url=http://rivals100.rivals.com/commitlist.asp?Year=2009&School=77|title=Stanford Commit List for 2009|publisher=[[Rivals.com]]|accessdate=2009-09-29}}{{cite web|url=http://recruiting.scout.com/a.z?s=73&p=9&c=8&toinid=734&yr=2009|title=Stanford 2009 Commits|publisher=[[Scout.com]]|accessdate=2009-09-29}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Name !Position !Hometown |- |Usua Amanam |RB |San Jose, CA |- |Zach Ertz |TE |Danville, CA |- |Tyler Gaffney |RB |San Diego, CA |- |Josh Nunes |QB |Upland, CA |- |Jamal-Rashad Patterson |WR |McDonough, GA |- |Jemari Roberts |WR |Long Beach, CA |- |Shayne Skov |LB |Pawling, NY |- |Terrence Stephens |DT |Gaithersburg, MD |- |Stepfan Taylor |RB |Mansfield, TX |- |Levine Toilolo |TE |San Diego, CA |} ==Schedule== {{CFB Schedule Start|time=|rank=|ranklink=|rankyear=2009|tv=|attend= yes}} {{CFB Schedule site_cityst = [[El Paso, Texas]] | gamename = [[2009 Sun Bowl|Sun Bowl]] | tv = [[CBS Sports|CBS]] | score = 27â31 | overtime = | attend = 53,713 }} {{CFB Schedule End|rank=|poll=[[AP Poll]]|timezone=[[Pacific Time Zone|Pacific Time]]{{cite web|url=http://www.gostanford.com/sports/m-footbl/sched/stan-m-footbl-sched.html|title=Stanford Football 2009-2010 Schedule|publisher=GoStanford.com}}}} == Game notes == ===Washington State=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road='''Cardinal''' |R1=8||R2=14||R3=7||R4=10||RT= |Home=Cougars |H1=0||H2=3||H3=10||H4=0||HT= }} {{seealso|2009 Washington State Cougars football team}} [[Toby Gerhart]] rushed for 121 yards and two touchdowns, and redshirt freshman quarterback [[Andrew Luck]] made his collegiate debut by throwing for 193 yards and a touchdown pass to Chris Owusu as Stanford defeated Washington State in Pullman. The Cardinal dominated the first half, but as the second half began, the Cougars took the early momentum, driving 80 yards and scoring on a 5-yard pass from Kevin Lopina to Jared Karstetter. However, Owusu answered immediately for the Cardinal with an 85-yard kickoff return for a touchdown to keep the game out of reach.{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=292480265|title=Frosh Luck leads Stanford past Washington State|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-09-05}} ===Wake Forest=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Cardinal |R1=7||R2=10||R3=0||R4=0||RT= |Home='''Demon Deacons''' |H1=3||H2=0||H3=7||H4=14||HT= }} {{seealso|2009 Wake Forest Demon Deacons football team}} Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck threw two first half touchdown passes to Ryan Whalen, and Nate Whitaker added a 54-yard field goalâthe longest Stanford field goal in 20 yearsâto give the Cardinal a 17â3 lead at the half. But the Demon Deacons dominated the second half with three unanswered touchdowns: a 3-yard run from Mike Rinfrette, a 9-yard pass from quarterback [[Riley Skinner]] to Jordan Williams, and then, with 2 seconds left in the game, a one-yard keeper by Skinner to give Wake Forest its first lead in the game and the 24â17 victory.{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=292550154|title=Skinner's TD in last seconds lifts Wake Forest by Stanford|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-09-12}} ===San Jose State=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=Spartans |R1=0||R2=7||R3=3||R4=7||RT= |Home='''Cardinal''' |H1=14||H2=7||H3=21||H4=0||HT= }} {{seealso|2009 San Jose State Spartans football team}} Stanford's Chris Owusu returned the opening kickoff 94 yards for a touchdown to set the pace as Stanford routed San Jose State 42â17. Owusu also caught a touchdown pass from Andrew Luck, and Toby Gerhart rushed for two touchdowns. The Cardinal added another special teams touchdown on Richard Sherman's 48-yard punt return, and Corey Gatewood rounded out the scoring with a 23-yard interception return for a touchdown. The Spartans scored on a 1-yard pass from Jordan La Secla to Jalal Beauchman, a 14-yard run from Lamon Muldrow, and a 30-yard field goal by Tyler Cope.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=292620024|title=Owusu sparks Stanford to rout of San Jose St.|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-09-19}} ===Washington=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road=#24 Huskies |R1=7||R2=7||R3=0||R4=0||RT= |Home='''Cardinal''' |H1=14||H2=10||H3=3||H4=7||HT= }} {{seealso|2009 Washington Huskies football team}} The Cardinal rushed for 322 yards, including a career-best 200 yards from Toby Gerhart to down the Huskies. For the second week in a row, Chris Owusu returned the opening kickoff for a touchdown to start the scoring for Stanford. Soon after, the Huskies tied the score on a dropped lateral from Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck to tight end Jim Dray; neither Luck nor Dray realized the throw was not a forward pass, but Washington's Justin Glenn picked up the ball and ran it 51 yards for the touchdown. However, on the next play from scrimmage, Gerhart ran 60 yards for a score to put Stanford ahead to stay.{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=292690024|title=Stanford returns opening kick for TD, cruises by No. 24 Washington|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-09-26}} ===UCLA=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road= Bruins |R1= 3 |R2= 3 |R3= 0 |R4= 10 |R5= |Home= '''Cardinal''' |H1= 7 |H2= 7 |H3= 10 |H4= 0 |H5= }} {{seealso|2009 UCLA Bruins football team}} Coming into the game, the Bruins were the only undefeated team in the [[Pacific-10 Conference|Pac-10 Conference]] although they had yet to a play another Pac-10 team. [[Toby Gerhart]], the Cardinal's 237-pound tailback who had 138 yards against UCLA last year, is averaging 129 yards a game. After UCLA recovered a fumble, Kai Forbath kicked a 29-yard field goal to give the Bruins the early lead. Gerhart rushed 5 yards for a touchdown for Stanford in the first quarter and aided by a UCLA penalty in the second quarter, scored a second touchdown. The Bruins kicked a field goal before halftime, aided by a partially-blocked punt. With a 46-yard [[flea flicker (American football)|flea flicker]] in the third quarter to put Stanford in the red zone, Gerhart scored his third touchdown from the 5-yard line. He finished the game with 134 rushing yards. Later in the quarter, Nate Whitaker kicked a 29-yard field goal to give the Cardinal a 24â6 lead. The Bruins began the fourth quarter with a Johnathan Franklin 1-yard touchdown run to cut the lead to 11, and a Forbath 35-yard field goal with about four minutes left in the game cut the lead to 24â16. UCLA took over with 3 minutes left but was unable to complete the comeback.{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=292760024|title=Stanford finally takes down UCLA, keeps share of Pac-10 lead|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-10-03}} {{-}} ===Oregon State=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road= Cardinal |R1=0 |R2= 7 |R3= 7 |R4= 14 |R5= |Home= '''Beavers''' |H1= 14 |H2= 17 |H3= 0 |H4= 7 |H5= }} {{seealso|2009 Oregon State Beavers football team}} The Beavers scored on every drive in the first half to take a 31â7 halftime lead on their way to a 38â28 defeat of the Cardinal. [[Jacquizz Rodgers]] ran for a career high 189 yards and a school record-tying four touchdowns. His brother [[James Rodgers (football)|James]] added the fifth touchdown and a Justin Kahut 31-yard field goal completed the scoring for the Beavers. After falling behind early, Stanford was forced out of its usual Toby Gerhart-led power rushing game, though Gerhart still managed 96 yards and two touchdowns. Andrew Luck added two touchdown passes, one to Chris Owusu and another to Jim Dray.{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=292830204|title=Rodgers' four TDs help Oregon State drop Stanford|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-10-10}} {{-}} ===Arizona=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road= Cardinal |R1=14 |R2=14 |R3=10 |R4=0 |R5= |Home= '''Wildcats''' |H1=13 |H2=7 |H3=9 |H4=14 |H5= }} {{seealso|2009 Arizona Wildcats football team}} In a game that featured more than a thousand offensive yards, the Wildcats rallied back late to defeat the Cardinal. The quarterbacks were evenly matched: Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck threw for 423 yards and three touchdowns, while Arizona's Nick Foles also tossed three touchdown passes and had a total of 415 yards. Stanford's Toby Gerhart had 123 yards and two touchdowns. Arizona managed a total of just 138 rush yards, but 57 of those came on Nic Grigsby's go-ahead touchdown with under three minutes left. Stanford drove to the Arizona 17 with seconds to play, but a fourth-down pass to Chris Owusu was batted away and the Wildcats escaped with a victory.{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=292900012|title=Arizona erases 15-point deficit to clip Stanford|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-10-17}} {{-}} ===Arizona State=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road= Sun Devils |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=7 |R4=7 |R5= |Home= '''Cardinal''' |H1=10 |H2=14 |H3=0 |H4=9 |H5= }} {{seealso|2009 Arizona State Sun Devils football team}} Toby Gerhart rushed for more than 100 yards for the 15th time in his college career as the Cardinal downed the Sun Devils. All four Stanford touchdowns were on rushes, but uncharacteristically for Stanford, only one was by Gerhart. Fullback [[Owen Marecic]], who is almost exclusively used to block for Gerhart, scored on his seventh career carry; freshman Jamal-Rashad Patterson scored on a 22-yard reverse; and backup running back Stepfan Taylor had a 33-yard touchdown run. Arizona State scored on two Danny Sullivan touchdown passes, the last coming just before Sullivan left the game with a bruised knee.{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=292970024|title=Stanford uses balanced attack to top Arizona State|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-10-24}} {{-}} ===Oregon=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road= #7 Ducks |R1= 7 |R2= 7 |R3= 14 |R4= 14 |R5= |Home= '''Cardinal''' |H1= 17 |H2= 14 |H3= 14 |H4= 6 |H5= }} {{seealso|2009 Oregon Ducks football team}} The Cardinal surprised the Ducks, 51â42, to become bowl-eligible for the first time in eight years. Toby Gerhart ran for three touchdowns and a school-record 223 yards on 38 carries, breaking the previous record of 220 set by [[Jon Volpe]] in 1988. He also broke his single-season rushing record set last year with 1,217 yards. Andrew Luck finished 12 for 20 for 251 yards, throwing an 8-yard touchdown pass to Jim Dray in the second quarter and a 31-yarder to Chris Owusu after Oregon cut the Cardinal lead to 10 points early in the third quarter. Oregon closed within six points late in the fourth quarter following a missed Stanford field goal, but Stanford recovered the ensuing onside kick. A field goal with 11 seconds remaining put the game away.{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=293110024|title=Stanford rides Gerhart's legs past No. 8 Oregon|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-11-07}} {{-}} ===USC=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road= '''#25 Cardinal''' |R1= 14 |R2= 7 |R3= 7 |R4= 27 |R5= |Home= #11 Trojans |H1= 0 |H2= 7 |H3= 14 |H4= 0 |H5= }} {{seealso|2009 USC Trojans football team}} Facing its second top-10 opponent in as many weeks, Stanford won 55-21, handing USC a 34-point lossâits biggest loss of the [[Pete Carroll]] era and its biggest loss since 1966.{{cite news|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=293180030|title=Gerhart fuels Stanford's throttling of No. 9 USC|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=November 14, 2009}} Stanford's 55 points was the highest number of points any team had scored against a USC Trojans football team in the 121-year history of Trojan football.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2009/11/14/sports/AP-FBC-College-Football-Today.html|title=College Football Today|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=November 14, 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} The 55 points included three Toby Gerhart touchdown runs and one by Andrew Luck. Richard Sherman returned an interception of a [[Matt Barkley]] fourth-quarter pass to spark a 27-point fourth quarter to put away the Trojans and keep the Cardinal's slim [[Rose Bowl (game)|Rose Bowl]] hopes alive.{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=293180030|title= Gerhart fuels Stanford's throttling of No. 9 USC|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-11-07}} This was Stanford's third victory against USC in their last five games against each other at the Coliseum (Stanford winning 2001, [[2007 Stanford vs. Southern California football game|2007]], and 2009, with USC winning in 2003 and 2005). USC has defeated every other opponent in the Coliseum since Stanford's September 29, 2001 victory in the Coliseum.{{cite news|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/breaking-news/ci_13792076|title=Stanford A.D.: Harbaugh's new contract should be completed soon|author=Jon Wilner|date=November 15, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/15/sports/ncaafootball/15national.html|title=Stanford Stuns U.S.C. Again, This Time With a Rout|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=November 14, 2009}} It was the first defeat in a November game for the Trojans in Carroll's nine-season tenure. For the first time since Carroll's first season, USC lost more than two games in one season. For the second time in three weekends, Carroll suffered the worst loss of his USC tenure, the other being its game against the [[Oregon Ducks]]. This was the largest margin of victory for Stanford in a Stanford-USC game since the two teams' rivalry began in 1918.{{cite news|url=http://www.athlonsports.com/college-football/18061/game-day-part-ii|title=Smell the Roses|publisher=Athlon Sports|date=November 14, 2009|author=Nathan Rush}} Harbaugh became only the third coach in college football with a winning record against Carroll, going 2-1 in the three times the two coaches have faced each other. {{-}} ===California=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road= '''Golden Bears''' |R1= 3 |R2= 7 |R3= 14 |R4= 10 |R5= |Home= #14 Cardinal |H1= 14 |H2= 0 |H3= 7 |H4= 7 |H5= }} {{seealso|Big Game (football)|2009 California Golden Bears football team}} Both teams faced each other in the 112th Big Game with seven wins each, the first time this had happened since 1991.{{cite web |url=http://rivals.yahoo.com/ncaa/football/news?slug=ap-t25-california-stanford&prov=ap&type=lgns |title=No. 14 Stanford flying high into Big Game vs. Cal |publisher=Yahoo! Sports |accessdate=2009-11-22}} The Cardinal had scored a combined 106 points in two previous games against higher ranked opponents, with consecutive upsets over Oregon and USC, two teams which had blown out Cal 42-3 and 30-3, respectively. Cal also played its second game without star running back [[Jahvid Best]], again starting backup Shane Vereen. The Cardinal scored on their first possession when Toby Gerhart broke free on the game's third play for a 61-yard touchdown. After successfully blocking a punt, which gave Stanford field position on the Cal 19 yard line, Gerhart scored again on a 2-yard run. The Bears responded with a scoring drive of their own that resulted in a field goal. In the second quarter, a Cal drive was halted when Richard Sherman intercepted [[Kevin Riley]] deep in Stanford territory. The Cardinal were unable to capitalize on the turnover however, and the Bears went on a five minute scoring drive that saw Vereen score his first touchdown of the game on a 1-yard run with just over a minute left in the quarter to make it 14-10 Stanford at the half. Cal took its first lead in the third quarter with a 92 yard scoring drive resulting in a 4 yard run by Vereen. Stanford was able to move downfield in turn, but missed a 45 yard field goal. The Bears marched downfield again and scored on a 3 yard run by Vereen. Stanford responded on the ensuing possession by scoring on a 1 yard run by Gerhart. The Bears in turn scored in the beginning of the fourth quarter with a 12 yard pass from Riley to Marvin Jones. Midway through the quarter, the Cardinal put together an 87 yard touchdown drive which resulted in Gerhart getting his fourth score of the game on a 5 yard run. After getting the ball back with just under 4 minutes left in the game, Stanford attempted a [[fourth down conversion]] which failed. The Bears took possession on the Stanford 23 yard line, but ended up settling for a field goal, making the score 34-28 and giving the Cardinal a chance to win with more than two and a half minutes left if they could score a touchdown. Stanford started out with good field position at its 42 yard line and was able to drive down to the Cal 13 yard line. Cal linebacker Mike Mohammed saved the game for the Bears when he intercepted Cardinal quarterback Andrew Luck, allowing Riley to take three straight [[Quarterback kneel|knees]] and Cal to retain the [[Stanford Axe]].{{cite web |url=http://rivals.yahoo.com/ncaa/football/boxscore?gid=200911210063&page=plays |title=California 34, Stanford 28 - Play by Play |publisher=Yahoo! Sports |accessdate=2009-11-22}} The loss, as well as a double overtime win later in the day by [[2009 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]] over [[2009 Arizona Wildcats football team|Arizona]], eliminated Stanford from [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] contention and the possibility of sharing the Pac-10 conference title.{{cite web |url=http://rivals.yahoo.com/ncaa/football/recap;_ylt=AqPP8uBjpqaNpxLQwK_fdI4cvrYF?gid=200911210063 |title=Cal beats No. 14 Stanford 34-28 in Big Game |publisher=Yahoo! Sports |accessdate=2009-11-22}} Luck threw for 157 yards, while Gerhart rushed for 136 yards and all of Stanford's four touchdowns, tying a single Big Game record previously set by Cal players [[Chuck Muncie]] and Lindsey Chapman. Cal's victory marked the 100th coached by Jeff Tedford, matching [[Pappy Waldorf]] for the most wins at Cal in the modern era, with 67. Riley threw for 235 yards and a score, while Vereen had another career game, rushing for 193 yards on 42 carries with three scores.{{cite web |url=http://www.calbears.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/112109aab.html |title=Cal Football Postgame Notes - at Stanford (Saturday, November 21) |publisher=University of California |accessdate=2009-11-22}} {{-}} ===Notre Dame=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road= Fighting Irish |R1=14 |R2=10 |R3=7 |R4=7 |R5= |Home= '''Cardinal''' |H1=10 |H2=10 |H3=7 |H4=18 |H5= }} {{seealso|Notre Dame â Stanford rivalry|2009 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team}} In a nationally televised game, the Cardinal scored a last-minute touchdown to defeat the Fighting Irish 45â38. Cardinal running back Toby Gerhart made a strong statement for [[Heisman Trophy]] consideration, rushing for 205 yards and three touchdowns and throwing his first career touchdown pass to Ryan Whalen. The win was Stanford's first in the annual series since 2001. Notre Dame lost its sixth of the season, all six of which have been by a touchdown or less. Notre Dame quarterback [[Jimmy Clausen]] threw for 340 yards and five touchdowns, three to [[Golden Tate]] and two to [[Michael Floyd]]. The game was [[Charlie Weis]]'s final game as head coach of Notre Dame; he was fired the following Monday.{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=293320024|title= Weis' future hangs in limbo after Irish lose to Stanford|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-12-01}}{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=4700891|title=Saying he fell short, ND fires Weis|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-12-01}} ===Oklahoma (Sun Bowl)=== {{Linescore Amfootball| |Road= '''Sooners''' |R1=10 |R2=7 |R3=14 |R4=0 |R5= |Home= #19 Cardinal |H1=7 |H2=17 |H3=0 |H4=3 |H5= }} {{main|2009 Sun Bowl}} {{see also|2009 Oklahoma Sooners football team}} Stanford made its first bowl appearance since 2001 without starting quarterback [[Andrew Luck]], who was sidelined due to a broken finger. [[Tavita Pritchard]], who hadn't started a game at quarterback since the [[2008 Stanford Cardinal football team|2008 season]], played the entire game, and was 8 for 19 with two interceptions as the Sooners outlasted the Cardinal 31â27. Toby Gerhart, who had finished second in the closest [[Heisman Trophy]] race ever a few weeks earlier, ran for 135 on 32 carries and scored two touchdowns for Stanford. Meanwhile, Sooners wide receiver [[Ryan Broyles]] set a Sun Bowl record with three touchdown receptions and was named Sun Bowl MVP. Broyles had 156 yards receiving and set Oklahoma's single-game record with 13 receptions from quarterback [[Landry Jones]], who passed for 418 yards overall.{{cite web|url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=293650024|title=Broyles' 3 TDs set Sun Bowl record as Sooners sink Cardinal|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-12-31}} ==Coaches== [[Image:Jim Harbaugh in 2007.jpg|thumb|Head Coach Jim Harbaugh]] *[[Jim Harbaugh]] - Head Coach *Andy Buh - Co-Defensive Coordinator/Linebackers Coach *[[Ron Lynn]] - Co-Defensive Coordinator/Assistant Head Coach *[[David Shaw (American football)|David Shaw]] - Offensive Coordinator/Wide Receivers *Lance Anderson - Assistant Coach - Defensive Line *Tim Drevno - Assistant Coach - Offensive Line/Centers and Guards *D.J. Durkin - Assistant Coach - DE/Special Teams *Greg Roman - Tight Ends/Offensive Tackles/Running Game Coordinator *[[Willie Taggart]] - Assistant Coach - Running Backs *Clayton White - Assistant Coach - Defensive Backs *Shannon Turley - Strength and Conditioning Coordinator *Matt Doyle - Assistant AD/Dir. of Football Operations *Mike Eubanks - Assistant AD/Director of Football Administration *Dave Forman - Assistant Strength and Conditioning Coach ==Rankings== {{See also|2009 NCAA Division I FBS football rankings}} {| class="wikitable" style="white-space:nowrap;" |+ Ranking Movement
